name: General Knowledge 10 Trivia Game | Mixed 25 Questions | 25 Questions

questions.text: Who played the pointy eared half-Vulcan, half-human Mr. Spock in the TV series 'Star Trek'?
questions.explanation:
Leonard Nimoy.

	Star Trek was created by former LA cop Gene Roddenberry.

questions.text: Which bird feeds mostly on fish?
questions.explanation:
Osprey.

	It dives into water to get hold of fish with its talons and is often called the 'fish hawk'. The roadrunner feeds on ground animals including snakes.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT one of Santa's reindeer?
questions.explanation:
Comma.

	Dasher, Dancer, Prancer, Vixen, Comet, Cupid, Donder/Donner and Blitzen. Not forgetting the most famous one of all, Rudolph. (Special thanks to 'lucee222' who pointed out the reindeer 'Donder' not 'Donner' as originally spelt. More investigation shows that some controversy exists still, so both names are now shown.)

questions.text: Which Greek island is also known as Zante? Thousands of Brits visit every year!
questions.explanation: Zakynthos.

questions.text: What was the name of Princess Diana's butler accused with stealing 302 items belonging to Diana?
questions.explanation: Paul Burrell.

questions.text: Which of the following member of 'Only Fools and Horses' has appeared in the film 'The Full Monty'?
questions.explanation:
Paul Barber (Denzil).

	He plays the character 'Horse'. Other characters in 'The Full Monty' include, Robert Carlyle as 'Gaz', Mark Addy as 'Dave', Tom Wilkinson as 'Gerald', Steve Huison as 'Lomper', Hugo Speer as 'Guy' and Willian Snape as Gaz's headstrong son 'Nathan'.

questions.text: In Dickens, what was the first name of Mr. Micawber?
questions.explanation:
Wilkins.

	David Jason plays 'Micawber' based on the Charles Dickens character who tries to support his wife and foundling kids despite for ever being broke.

questions.text: Name the character part played by Charlie Sheen in the film 'Hot Shots' (1991)?
questions.explanation: Topper Harley.

questions.text: In the 1970's TV version of 'Planet of the Apes' what was the character played by Roddy McDowall?
questions.explanation:
Galen.

	The film was based on a novel by Pierre Boulle.

questions.text: What relation was Morgan le Fay to King Arthur?
questions.explanation:
Half - sister.

	She was a legendary enchantress and was generally hostile towards King Arthur. Morgan le Fay is in Malory's 'Morte d'Arthur' Arthur's half-sister, the daughter of Arthur's mother Igraine and her first husband the Duke of Cornwall.

questions.text: Who was born with the name Krishna Bhanji?
questions.explanation:
Ben Kingsley.

	He won an Oscar for his performance in the film 'Gandhi'(1982).

questions.text: Cult film director Peter Jackson utilised which country's locations for filming 'Lord of the Rings : The Fellowship of the Ring'?
questions.explanation:
New Zealand.

	This New Zealand film director uses New Zealand locations and seamless special effects to create Middle Earth.

questions.text: Who was the film director of 'Honey, I Shrunk the Kids' and 'Jumanji'?
questions.explanation:
Joe Johnston.

	The alternative choices were famous snooker personalities. Joe Johnson (not Joe Johnston) was the 1986 World professional snooker champion.

questions.text: In Disney's 'Toy Story II' what was the name of Andy's dog?
questions.explanation: Buster.

questions.text: Name the Missouri farmer's son who dubbed the designers of Disneyland 'Imagineers'?
questions.explanation:
Walt Disney.

	He scooped a total of 32 personal Academy Awards. In 1965 he purchased 27,443 acres of land outside Orlando, Florida which would become the site for Walt Disney World.

questions.text: Name the British conductor born in 1955: Sir Simon ... ?
questions.explanation: Rattle.

questions.text: Which of the following words does NOT appear in the acronym 'NICAM' as in Nicam sound?
questions.explanation:
Natural.

	Near Instantaneous Companded Audio Multiplex.

questions.text: Which sea links the countries of China and Japan?
questions.explanation: Sea of Japan.

questions.text: How many of the following American states have the mockingbird as the state bird: Texas, Tennessee, Mississippi and Florida?
questions.explanation:
All.

	Also the state of Arkansas.

questions.text: The Nobel Peace Prize is awarded in which Scandinavian country?
questions.explanation:
Norway.

	All the other prizes are awarded in Sweden.

questions.text: The Norse god Odin was the keeper of all knowledge. His horse galloped through the air but how many legs did it have?
questions.explanation:
8.

	Odin was represented as an old, one-eyed, bearded man wearing a multicoloured robe and a wide-brimmed hat.

questions.text: Name the Scottish artist who won the recent controversial 'Turner Prize' for a light that turns on and off: Martin ...  ?
questions.explanation: Creed.

questions.text: Father Christmas was famous for giving out presents to poor children. He was based on Saint Nicholas as a bishop from which country?
questions.explanation:
Turkey.

	He lived in the third century A.D.

questions.text: Which Greek hero was shut in a chest and thrown into the sea by his grandfather?
questions.explanation:
Perseus.

	He was washed up on the island of Seriphos where the island's tyrant demanded that he bring him the head of a Gorgon as a gift. He slew Medusa.

questions.text: Name the woman who originated 'Murder Mystery Weekend Breaks' and became an M.B.E. this year for services to tourism?
questions.explanation:
Joy Swift.

	She spent the last twenty years turning historic homes into crime spots. Hope you enjoyed the quiz.
